Metal/biochar catalysts are prepared by direct impregnation of metal salts with biochar produced from pyrolysis. However, the surface structure of the catalyst carrier is affected by the pyrolysis temperature. Different pyrolysis temperatures can produce different pore structures, which can affect the dispersion of active metals. To verify this, Cu/bone biochar catalysts were prepared by directly supporting copper nitrate on the biochar from chicken bone pyrolysis at 400, 500, 650, and 800 °C, respectively. Catalytic performance of Cu/bone biochar catalysts for vanillin hydrogenation was evaluated. The results showed that the hydroxyapatite produced after pyrolysis of chicken bones was relatively stable, which made the catalyst with superior activity and reusability. The catalyst prepared by pyrolysis at a lower temperature had fewer pore structures on its surface, and the active metal Cu was easily sintered. With increasing pyrolysis temperature, organic matter gradually decreased and more pore structures were generated on the surface of the catalyst carrier, which was more conducive to the dispersion of metallic Cu species. The catalyst prepared from the chicken bone pre-pyrolyzed at 800 °C exhibited uniform dispersion of metal Cu, with the average particle size of Cu particles of 11.9 nm, achieving the yield of 91.7 % for 2‑methoxy-4-methyl phenol from hydrogenation of vanillin. In-situ IR characterizations also showed that, with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the surface functional groups of the catalyst were more conducive to the hydrogenation of vanillin. Graphical abstract The effect of pyrolysis temperature on pore structure and dispersion of metallic Cu of metal/biochar catalysts was investigated for conversion of vanillin. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu/bone biochar catalysts Hydrogenation Vanillin Pyrolysis Chicken bone Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Poultry industry is a fast-growing industry, which is propelled by rapid expansion of population globally [1]. For example, the number of chickens was 25.8 billion worldwide in 2021, which was almost doubled the number of chickens in 2000 (14.38 billion) [2]. Most of chickens are ended as meat for consumption by humans. Nevertheless, chicken bone (CB) is not food for people, part of which are converted as low-value products such as feed, while another significant portion is discarded as kitchen waste [3,4]. Since collagen and marrow on/in bonds cannot be separated completely from bones, which could serve as culture medium for microorganism and bacteria. Therefore, some technical routes need to be developed to make best use of bone wastes like CB [5,6]. There have been studies proposing to convert CB to CaO catalyst via for catalyzing transesterification reactions for production of biodiesel from cooking oil [7,8]. For example, the heterogeneous catalyst derived from chicken bones to prepare biodiesel or fatty acid ethyl ester via transesterification reactions [9,10]. Nevertheless, the transformation of CB to CaO requires calcination at very high temperature (typically > 1000 °C), which is an energy-intensive process and increases the cost for production of CB-derived solid base catalyst [6,11]. This is mainly because CB contains inorganic materials mainly in the form of hydroxyapatite that is thermally rather stable [12]. Except hydroxyapatite, CB typically also contains collagen and marrow, which are carbonaceous and can decompose at high pyrolysis temperature. This could potentially generate porous structures [13]. Thus, CB after removing carbonaceous organics could be also used support of heterogeneous catalysts such as metal/bone catalyst [14]. Compared to the bare metal counterparts, copper combined with other materials like biochar could offer enhancement in catalytic performance and reduce material costs [15–17]. In preparation of such type of catalyst, the correlation of porous structures of the bones like CB with cracking of collagen/marrow at varied temperatures needs to be clarified. It is because this would affect dispersion of metal species on bone carrier [18,19]. Further to this, in addition to inorganics, residual organics might also interact with metals and affect exposure of metals in the catalyst [20–22]. Understanding how do transformation of collagen/marrow correlate to dispersion of metals is of importance to optimize methods for preparation of metal/bone catalyst [23–25]. In this study, waste CB from catering industry was pyrolysed at 400, 500, 650, or 800 °C, respectively [26–28]. The purpose was to retain different content of the carbonaceous residual from collagen/marrow in the CB, for further understanding how do these organics influence dispersion of Cu species introduced via impregnation of Cu(NO3)2 solution [29,30]. The prepared Cu/CB catalyst was characterized systematically and evaluated in hydrogenation of vanillin [31–33]. The dispersion of Cu was correlated to pore structures and content of organics in pyrolyzed CB [34]. The reaction kinetics for the hydrogenation were measured while the reaction intermediates involved in hydrogenation were characterized with in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The results show that the nature of the organic residual from pyrolysis of CB at varied temperature significantly affected development of pore structure, the morphology, the functionalities, the hydrophilicity, the dispersion of Cu, the adsorption of reaction intermediates, the catalytic activity and selectivity of Cu/CB catalysts. Experimental Materials The chicken skeleton was purchased from a shop in a food market (Jinan, China), which was chopped into pieces and cleaned four times with deionized water. The CB sample was then dried for 24 h at 105 °C, and then was pyrolysed. Vanillin was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. and ethanol was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (China). Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with a purity of 99% was obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All reagents were analytical grade. Preparation of the catalysts The synthesis procedure of catalyst was shown in Fig. S1. Before preparation of the catalyst, dried CB was pyrolyzed in a furnace heated at a ramping rate of 10 ℃/min to 400, 500, 650 or 800 °C and held for 3 h. The CB was wrapped with multiple layers of alumina foil to create an air-deficient environment. After that, the obtained CB was further crushed and ground to prepare CB as a catalyst carrier with the diameter of 0.5 to 1 mm. The CB from different temperature was termed as CB-temperature. Cu(NO3)2 as precursor of Cu was used to prepare the Cu/CB catalyst by an incipient wetness impregnation method. Specifically, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O of a certain weight was dissolved in 10 g deionized water and then CB was added to the Cu(NO3)2 solution and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The sample was further dried and ground to obtain the catalyst precursor. The prepared precursor samples were calcined in a tubular furnace in a N2 flow of 60 mL/min at 300 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. After cooling to room temperature, the samples were reduced at 300 °C in a mixed N2 and H2 flow (rate: 60/60 mL/min) to obtain the Cu/CB in reduced form. The loading of Cu in metal form to CB was 15 wt% for all the prepared catalysts. Catalytic experiments Performance of the catalyst was evaluated with hydrogenation of vanillin, carried out in an autoclave reactor (10 mL in volume) containing a magnetic stirrer. 40 mg catalyst and 4 g of the reaction substrate - solvent mixture was added (vanillin: 1.0 mol) was loaded for the catalytic reaction. 3 MPa H2 was fed in at room temperature after purging the reactor with H2 for three times. The autoclave reactor was heated to the reaction temperature within 30 min and held for 2 h with a magnetic stirrer rotating at 600 r/min. The catalyst was recovered and separated from liquid product via filtration after finishing the experiment. Characterizations of the catalysts Crystal phase of the catalysts was characterized with X-ray diffraction spectrometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima Ⅳ) equipped with a Cu target (K α-radiation source, λ = 1.5406 Å). The scope of the diffraction angle was 10.0° to 80.0° with a scanning speed of 20°/min. The particle size of metallic Cu species was calculated by Debye-Scherrer equation. The BUILDER SSA-6000 aperture specific surface area analyzer was used to analyze pore structure of the sample after being preprocessed in vacuum for 3 h at 200 °C for the removal of physically adsorbed components. N2 adsorption-desorption characterization was accomplished at 77 K, the pore size and specific surface area were calculated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method. The elemental content of biochar, including C, N, H and O, was analyzed with EuroEA3000-Single instrument (Italy). H2-TPR analysis of the calcined samples was conducted with Vodo VDSorb 91x instrument (China). The reduction degree of the Cu metal was calculated with the amount of hydrogen consumed. Specifically, 10 mg sample was reduced in a 5 % H2/Ar gases with a flow rate of 10 mL/min and the temperature was raised to 500 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min. The signal is recorded with a TCD. N2O chemisorption was used to determine the dispersion of Cu. Firstly, the sample was placed in an Ar flow (40.0 mL/min), heated to 120 °C and kept for 1 h. 5 % H2/Ar mixed gas (40.0 mL/min) was then injected and reduced the sample for one hour at 300 °C. Ar flow (40.0 mL/min) was further used to treat it and cooled it to 60 °C. After this, N2O flow rate of 40 mL/min was injected for 1 h, metallic Cu in the sample was oxidized to Cu2O, and then Cu2O was reduced to Cu metal again with H2/Ar flow (40.0 mL/min) during the heating to 300 °C at 5 °C/min. Calculation of metal dispersion of copper was based on that in literature [29]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100 plus) and scanning electron microscope (SEM, EM-30 Plus, Korea) were used to analyze morphology of the catalysts, and contact angle goniometer (Powereach, JC2000D1, China) was used to explore the hydrophilicity of the catalyst surface. Functionalities of reaction intermediates during the hydrogenation were measured by in-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (DRIFTS, Nicolet iS50, America). Typically, the reduced copper-based catalyst was ground uniformly and then loaded into DRIFTS cell, and then the reactant solution was dripped onto the surface of the catalyst. After that, a H2 flow (40.0 mL/min) was introduced during the heating to 170 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min and holding time of 1 h at the ending temperature. The FT-IR spectra were continuously recorded. Analysis of liquid products Liquid products from the hydrogenation were analyzed by using a gas chromatography coupling with a mass spectrometer (GC–MS, Shimadzu GC−MS−QP 2020), equipped with a capillary column (0.25 μm of film thickness, 0.25 mm of internal diameter, 30 m of length) for separating different organics. Conversion of vanillin and yield of a product were calculated with the equations below. C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = M o l e o f reactant c o n v e r t e d M o l e o f r e a c t a n t l o a d e d × 100 % Y i e l d ( % ) = M o l e o f pro d u c t p r o d u c e d M o l e o f r e a c t a n t l o a d e d × 100 % The Arrhenius equation used in kinetic study is as follows: k = A ex p ( − Ea / RT ) k is the rate constant; A is a pre-exponential factor; Ea is the activation energy; R is the universal gas constant and T is the temperature. Results and discussion Characterization of the catalysts XRD analysis Fig. 1 showed the diffraction peaks of Cu/CB after impregnation, calcination, reduction and use in hydrogenation of vanillin. As shown in Fig. 1a, obvious diffraction peaks of hydroxyapatite at 25.7° and 31.7° (JCPDS 09–0432) were observed in the biochar prepared at the different pyrolysis temperatures. CB was mainly composed of hydroxyapatite with high thermal stability. After impregnation and calcination, the diffraction peaks of hydroxyapatite phase showed little change while the CuO phase formed from decomposition of Cu(NO3)2, with the diffraction observed at 35.1°and 38.5°(JCPDS 44–0706). The weak diffraction of CuO indicated the crystallinity of CuO on surface of CB was low. After reduction with H2 at 300 °C, the diffraction peaks centered at 43.1°, 50.2° and 73.9°, belonged to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal faces of Cu, were observed [29,35]. The higher diffraction peak of Cu in Cu/CB-400 suggested a significant portion of copper species located on surface of CB-400 [36]. The particle sizes of Cu in Table 1 were clearly higher than that of CuO, which was possibly due to the weak interaction of copper species with the CB support. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, crystalline size of Cu metal in the corresponding Cu-based catalysts decreased slightly (Table 1, Entries 1 to 4), which might be related to the textural structure of CB supports. This was further investigated by N2 adsorption and desorption. BET and elemental analysis Fig. 2 showed the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the Cu/CB catalysts with the CB carrier obtained at different pyrolysis temperatures. Cu/CB-400 showed typical type III isotherms, suggesting formation of little micropores and mesopores [37]. The pyrolysis of CB at 400 °C could not effectively crack collagen/marrow in the CB, forming limited pore structures and leading to pile up of copper on outer surface of the CB (Table 1). For the CB obtained at the temperature above 500 °C, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms changed to typical type IV with H4 hysteresis loop, suggesting the formation of mesoporous structure [38,39]. This was induced by the cracking of the organic matters at the higher pyrolysis temperatures. For Cu/CB-800, some macropores were even formed at the expense of mesopores, indicating merge of some mesopores at the high temperatures. The removal of the organic matters from the CB feedstock could also be evidenced by the elemental analysis in Table 2 . With the temperature increasing, the ash content in biochar gradually increased while the C content decreased, indicated that the organic matters in the raw material were gradually removed [40]. It could also be demonstrated by the biochar yield shown in Table S1. The removal of the organics from biochar was accompanied with development of the pore structures. The H species were rather thermally unstable and could be removed easily above 400 °C. H2-TPR and N2O chemisorption Reduction behaviors of Cu-/CB catalysts are shown in Fig. 3c , while reduction degree of CuO was also calculated (Table 3 ). The reduction peaks of Cu-Cu/CB catalysts were around 300℃ and 450 °C, indicating varied level of interaction of copper species with the CB support. The first reduction peak at ca. 300 °C attributed to the free-standing copper oxides [41,42], which, however, shifted to lower temperature region with the increasing pyrolysis temperature. The removal of organic matters at high pyrolysis temperature seemed to reduce interactions with CB support. However, the second peak at ca. 450 °C showed opposite trend, which could be due to the entering of copper oxide into the inner pores that created a higher mass transfer limitation [43]. The reduction degree in Table 3 showed that the gradually increasing pyrolysis temperature of CB facilitated reduction of copper oxide. This could be due to the elimination of the effects of organics such as wrapping, covering, etc. Table 3 also showed the dispersion and surface area of Cu obtained by N2O chemisorption (Fig. S2a and Fig. S2b). Compared with Cu/CB-400, the other catalysts with CB obtained at higher pyrolysis temperature showed higher Cu dispersion and larger Cu surface area. Additionally, the higher the temperature for pyrolysis, the higher the dispersion of metallic Cu. This was related to the developed mesopore structures of the catalysts with the CB produced at higher pyrolysis temperature. Although the Cu/CB-800 showed lower overall specific surface area than Cu/CB-650, the former catalyst possessed more macropores, which facilitated the reduction and exposure of metallic Cu species. FT-IR and contact angle analysis Fig. 3a and 3b shows FT-IR spectra of raw CB feedstock and Cu/CB catalysts. The absorption at ca. 3400 cm−1 was ascribed to the bending vibration of -OH [44]. The absorption at 2925 and 2854 cm−1 attributed to the CH stretching vibration, and the absorption at about 1639 cm−1 was attributed to C = O while the absorption peak of 1030 cm−1 was ascribed to aliphatic CO-C [31,45]. FT-IR spectra showed that the peak intensity of the main functional groups of CB decreased with the increase of pyrolysis temperature. This was clearly due to their removal at higher temperature. The C = O could be cracked even at 400 °C, but not completely even at 650 or 800 °C (Fig. 3b). These oxygen-containing functional groups could probably promote dispersion of Cu. The organics bearing olefinic C = C were relatively more stable, while the CO-C for bridging benzene ring structures was more stable. They might be interacting with copper species in some ways. Contact angles of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 . The Cu/CB-400 contact angle was initially 89° and decreased slowly to 86° in 4 s. It showed that the catalyst was more hydrophobic at low temperature. Except Cu/CB-400, other catalysts were all highly hydrophilic. This was because of the exposure of the inorganics like hydroxyapatite that was rather hydrophilic. The hydrophilicity of catalysts was related to the functional groups on its surface and the content of inorganic substances. Although pyrolysis at high temperature led to removal of more organics, in the meantime more inorganics like hydroxyapatite were also exposed, which became the main factor affecting hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of the catalyst. As shown in Table 2, the increase of pyrolysis temperature removed more organic matter, and the ash content gradually increased. In comparison, Cu/CB-400 contained a higher content of organic matters and the pyrolysis of these organics formed carbonaceous surface with hydrophobic properties, and it had the smallest specific surface area, preventing the catalysts from interacting with water. The hydrophobic nature of the carrier was not desirable for anchoring of copper ions and adsorption of polar reaction substrates in hydrogenation [46]. SEM and tem analysis Fig. 5 showed morphology of the Cu/CB catalysts with the CB support obtained at different pyrolysis temperatures. Surface of Cu/CB-400 was composed by concave layers with piled particles, which was related to the organic residual on surface of CB. Over the CB produced with the increasing pyrolysis temperature above 500 °C, the flower-like structure appeared, which should be attributed to the copper species. The structure was rather thermally stable and did not change much with even the temperature increased to 800 °C. In order to further analyze the reasons for the formation of the flower-like structure, the CB was oxidized at 800 °C before being used as support for loading copper. As shown in Fig. S3, only the columnar structure was observed after loading metal Cu for Cu/CB-800-oxidized. The carbonaceous organics derived from the degradation of CB via the pyrolysis were responsible for the formation of the flower-like structures. The potential contribution of copper for formation of the flower-like structure was also investigated by loading copper to SBA-15. As expected, no flower-like structures were identified. Organic residual in CB played the key roles for formation of the unique surface morphology. Fig. 6 showed the TEM images of Cu/CB-800 catalyst. Cu was uniformly dispersed on the CB carrier, and the average particle size of Cu particles was 11.9 nm [47]. The mapping results in Fig. 6c further indicated that Cu species dispersed uniformly across surface of CB [48,49]. The influence of the temperature for pyrolysis of CB on the catalytic activity was further investigated in hydrogenation of vanillin. Catalytic activity Hydrogenation of vanillin Table 4 showed the conversion of vanillin and distribution of products in the hydrogenation over the Cu/CB catalysts. The catalytic performances of Cu/CB-650 and Cu/CB-800 were clearly much higher than that of Cu/CB-500 and Cu/CB-400, while Cu/CB-400 showed almost no activity for hydrogenation of vanillin. The metal dispersion in Cu/CB-400 and coverage of copper species also inhibited exposure of copper species [33,50]. Further to this, the hydrophobic nature of Cu/CB-400 was also undesirable for adsorption of vanillin on surface of the catalysts. The more developed pore structures and higher dispersion of copper species of Cu/CB-650 and Cu/CB-800 resulted in the enhanced activity for hydrogenation. However, Cu/CB-800 showed much higher yield for the synthesis of 2‑methoxy-4-methyl phenol (MMP, yield: 91.7 %), which had a good performance in the current common catalysts as shown in Table S2 [31,33,50-56], while Cu/CB-650 was more selective for production of 4-(ethoxymethyl)−2‑methoxy-phenol (EMP), a product from etherification of MMP. Since etherification reactions were catalyzed with acidic sites on surface of catalyst, and thus the higher yields of MMP over was mainly due to the higher abundance of acidic sites of stronger strength over Cu/CB-650, as indicated in Fig. 3d and Table S3 [57,58]. In-situ drifts characterization The reaction intermediates generated during hydrogenation over Cu/CB-400 and Cu/CB-800 catalysts were further investigated with in-situ DRIFTS characterization via heating the catalyst with adsorbed vanillin in a hydrogen flow (Fig. 7 ). Since the vanillin used is a solid powder and cannot be introduced by bubbling method, it was dissolved in ethanol and then impregnated on surface of catalysts. The absorption peaks centered at 1671, 1563, 1334, and 1197 cm−1 can be attributed to the C = O, C = C, OH, and CO bonds in the vanillin molecule [55]. With the prolonging reaction time and increasing temperature, the intensity of the absorption peaks of various functional groups over catalysts changed (Fig. S4), which was due to the occurrence of hydrogenation reactions [59]. Typically, over Cu/CB-400, the absorption of -OH started to be appreciable above 150 °C, and this was accompanied with the decreased absorption of C = O, suggesting hydrogenation of carbonyl functionality in vanillin. The absorption of C = C in the benzene ring remained stable, as it was difficult to be hydrogenated. Over Cu/CB-800, the -C-H in the methoxy group and C = O of vanillin could be clearly identified at 30 °C, suggesting stronger adsorption of the oxygen-containing species on this catalyst [60]. This favored the hydrogenation of the C = O in vanillin, as evidenced by the evident -OH peak from 150 °C. This also corresponded to the better hydrogenation performance of the Cu/CB-800 catalyst. Kinetic study and catalytic recyclability The reaction kinetics of vanillin hydrogenation to MMP was studied over Cu/CB-800 catalyst with the best catalytic performance at four different reaction temperatures (110 °C, 130 °C, 150 °C and 170 °C), as shown in Fig. 8a and Table 5 . The activation energy could reach 24.1 kJ/mol and the reaction rate of catalyst gradually increased with the reaction temperature increasing. The reaction rate at 110 °C is 13.9 mmol·gcat −1·h − 1, while the reaction rate at 170 °C reaching 40.7 mmol·gcat −1·h − 1, which was double that of the former. This indicated that high temperature is more conducive to the hydrogenation of vanillin [61]. In order to further investigate the recyclability of Cu/CB catalysts, hydrogenation of vanillin with the catalysts recycled for four times were conducted (Fig. 8b). The Cu/CB-800 catalyst could generally maintain the activity for hydrogenation of vanillin, with MMP as the dominated products with the increase of the number of cycles for the hydrogenation [56,62,63]. As for Cu/CB-650 catalyst, its activity decreased in the second cycle in terms of the yield of EMP. Moreover, some product like 4-hydroxymethyl-2‑methoxy-phenol were produced with a low yield, suggesting the loss of also little acidic sites from surface of the Cu/CB-650 catalyst. In addition, the Cu/CB-500 catalyst still showed the low activity while The Cu/CB-400 catalyst exhibited almost no activity for the hydrogenation. The XRD characterization in Fig. 1d showed the little change of the crystal phases while the particle size of Cu also did not change much for the spent catalysts (Table 1), suggesting the acceptable catalytic and structural stability of the Cu/CB catalysts. Limitations and prospect The above results indicated that CB could be a feasible support for preparation of Cu-based catalyst for hydrogenation of vanillin and the organic matter in CB significantly impacted the catalytic activity. There, however, some remaining questions to be further answered. Firstly, the characterisation of dispersion of Cu and elemental measurement demonstrated the importance of the carbonaceous residual produced at the varied pyrolysis temperature in determining distribution of Cu species. The mechanism for the interactions of the organics with Cu species from impregnation to calcination or reduction of the catalyst precursors should be clarified. Secondly, the SEM characterisation also confirmed the essential roles of organic residual in CB in formation of the flower-like morphology. However, how do the organics induce the formation of such unique morphology could be further investigated. Thirdly, the CB contained mainly inorganics and how do these inorganics influence the dispersion of copper species and also the distribution of acidic sites should be further clarified. The potential catalytic roles of the inorganics in hydrogenation could also be studied. Fourthly, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption suggested that the CB had limited porous structures. How to activated the animal bones with inorganics as main components like CB to generate developed pore structures needs to be investigated. Conclusion In summary, the influence of organic matters in CB on physiochemical property and catalytic behaviors of Cu/CB catalyst in hydrogenation of vanillin was investigated. The results showed that the pyrolysis of CB at 400 °C could not induce substantial degradation of collagen/marrow in the CB, generating limited pore structures and leading to pile up of copper on CB as well as coverage of copper with the H-rich organic residual. In comparison, the cracking of collagen/marrow in the CB above 500 °C created mesoporous structure and even some macropores via merge of mesopores at 800 °C. Furthermore, the removal of organic matters also facilitated reduction of copper oxide, which together with the porous structure resulted in higher Cu dispersion and larger Cu surface area, especially for Cu/CB-800 (Cu surface area: 12.1 m2g−1) with plentiful macropores, even though it showed lower overall specific surface area than Cu/CB-650 (Cu surface area: 7.0 m2g−1). Additionally, higher content of organics in Cu/CB-400 resulted in the surface of concave layers with piled particles, while the other Cu/CB catalysts with pyrolysis of CB above 500 °C all showed flower-like structure. The carbonaceous residual derived from CB was the key for formation of such morphology. The catalytic performances of Cu/CB catalysts were closely related to the pyrolysis temperature of CB. Cu/CB-650 and Cu/CB-800 were superior to Cu/CB-500, while Cu/CB-400 showed almost no activity for hydrogenation, relating to the low copper dispersion and hydrophobic surface. Additionally, Cu/CB-800 with more overall acidic sites was more active for hydrogenolysis of reaction intermediates, while Cu/CB-650 with more strong acidic sites was more active for catalyzing etherification to form more ether product. In-situ DRIFTS characterization of the hydrogenation showed that stronger adsorption of the oxygen-containing species over Cu/CB-800 was one major reason for its superior catalytic activity for hydrogenation. The kinetic study showed that the reaction rate was very sensitive to reaction temperature and could increase three-fold from 110 to 170 °C. In addition, the recyclability tests showed that Cu/CB-800 catalyst could generally maintain the activity for hydrogenation of vanillin with little structural changes. The animal bone-based carrier is hydrothermally stable, but the limited porous structures is an issue to be further tackled. coredata.dc:description: Metal/biochar catalysts are prepared by direct impregnation of metal salts with biochar produced from pyrolysis. However, the surface structure of the catalyst carrier is affected by the pyrolysis temperature. Different pyrolysis temperatures can produce different pore structures, which can affect the dispersion of active metals. To verify this, Cu/bone biochar catalysts were prepared by directly supporting copper nitrate on the biochar from chicken bone pyrolysis at 400, 500, 650, and 800 °C, respectively. Catalytic performance of Cu/bone biochar catalysts for vanillin hydrogenation was evaluated. The results showed that the hydroxyapatite produced after pyrolysis of chicken bones was relatively stable, which made the catalyst with superior activity and reusability. The catalyst prepared by pyrolysis at a lower temperature had fewer pore structures on its surface, and the active metal Cu was easily sintered. With increasing pyrolysis temperature, organic matter gradually decreased and more pore structures were generated on the surface of the catalyst carrier, which was more conducive to the dispersion of metallic Cu species. The catalyst prepared from the chicken bone pre-pyrolyzed at 800 °C exhibited uniform dispersion of metal Cu, with the average particle size of Cu particles of 11.9 nm, achieving the yield of 91.7 % for 2‑methoxy-4-methyl phenol from hydrogenation of vanillin. In-situ IR characterizations also showed that, with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the surface functional groups of the catalyst were more conducive to the hydrogenation of vanillin.
coredata.dc:title: Flower-like Cu/bone biochar for hydrogenation of vanillin: Importance of evolution of organic matter in chicken bone on property of the catalysts
